label: q_it05_q22_counterfactual
content:
{
  "question_id": "it05_q22_counterfactual",
  "scope_id": "insider_threat_05",
  "checkpoint_after": 20,
  "question_type": "counterfactual",
  "prompt": "If the elevated data transfers were caused by a legitimate project requiring large file downloads, what pattern would you expect? Does the data match?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "Legitimate project work would show data access confined to current project repositories, during standard work hours, with organizational justification. Instead, jmorris is accessing archived projects outside their assignment, extending sessions to late night, and uploading encrypted files to personal cloud storage.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "insider_threat_05_ep_016",
      "insider_threat_05_ep_017"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "lateral information gathering pattern inconsistent with declared operational role",
      "data transfer volumes from a single account diverge from peer group norms in a sustained multi-week pattern",
      "data transfer volumes escalated progressively over a multi-week period with each successive week showing higher peak transfer sizes than the previous",
      "the anomalous data access pattern originates from a single authorized internal account, not from external network intrusion",
      "the data exfiltration uses authorized access paths rather than exploiting software vulnerabilities",
      "red team exercise alerts are not related to the exfiltration activity",
      "the exfiltration vector uses legitimate credentials and existing access rights rather than exploiting misconfigurations",
      "departing employee access anomalies warrant immediate credential revocation and forensic evidence preservation"
    ]
  }
}
